pull.title: security: restrict abis in bitcoind.service
pull.body:
[As noted here](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.exec.html#MemoryDenyWriteExecute=), it's a good idea to pair `MemoryDenyWriteExecute=true` with `SystemCallArchitectures=native` because `MemoryDenyWriteExecute` can be circumvented in some operating systems which support multiple ABIs like x86/x86-64.
This helps restrict the possible application binary interfaces (ABIs) that can be used when running bitcoind through systemd, reducing the attack surface area.

verification.payload:
tree cee3c26fd5803b5b7668431b3ad1ece403c054b1
parent 5ce200dda23752cf8bf6dccb23aea4b23f1653ae
author Charlie <2747302+CharlieC3@users.noreply.github.com> 1692910487 -0400
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1692910487 -0400

security: restrict abis in bitcoind.service

It's recommended to restrict the possible application binary interfaces that can be used when setting `MemoryDenyWriteExecute=true` to ensure it cannot be circumvented.

If your review is incorrectly listed, please react with ðŸ‘Ž to this comment and the bot will ignore it on the next update.

Probably Concept ACK, because nix-bitcoin does this too: https://github.com/fort-nix/nix-bitcoin/blob/master/pkgs/lib.nix

Might as well consider _all_ the extra stuff they added there.

ACK 0244416aacbad03e4ebe8f2c95c7861a318916ea . This is a sensible security feature.
It looks like [the documentation](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/latest/systemd.exec.html) of systemd.exec even mentions this pairing.

I do agree with @sjors, however, that when we're adding systemd hardening options, we might as well look further.
